Project.Brief history of your project and organi: The Meteorological Satellite Center, established to advance weather forecasting, began operating the Geostationary Meteorological Satellite (GMS) series, starting with "Himawari" in 1978. It progressed to launching the advanced Himawari-8 and Himawari-9 satellites in 2014 and 2016, respectively, enhancing weather and environmental monitoring across the Asia-Pacific. The MSC introduced data services like HimawariCast and HimawariCloud in 2015 for efficient data dissemination to meteorological services, supports global weather prediction and disaster mitigation.
Project.Describe the data being stored onto File: The Meteorological Satellite Center stores Himawari-8 and Himawari-9 satellite data. This includes high-resolution, multi-spectral imagery captured, covering weather patterns, typhoons, and environmental phenomena in the Asia-Pacific region. The data, available at various spatial resolutions, supports meteorological forecasting and disaster monitoring.
Project.How do you plan to prepare the dataset: To prepare Himawari-8 and Himawari-9 satellite data, we first download the data from AWS S3, verifying integrity against metadata. The imagery, which includes high-resolution multi-spectral data updated, is segmented into chunks using Singularity, with files split into smaller parts and packaged into CAR files, each assigned a unique PieceCID. Metadata, including file sizes, split counts, and packaging details, is stored in a PostgreSQL database for indexing and CID-based retrieval. These CAR files are then proposed to selected Storage Providers via Singularity’s deal-making API, ensuring efficient and decentralized storage.
Project.In which geographies do you plan on maki: Australia (continent), Asia other than Greater China, Greater China, North America, South America, Europe, Africa
Project.How will you be distributing your data t: HTTP or FTP server, IPFS, Lotus built-in data transfer, Venus built-in data transfer
